Synthesis of 4-styrylquinazolines using copper-based porous solid catalyst Jayaraman Krishnan a Karuppuchamy Ranjithkumar a Amarajothi Dhakshinamoorthy a b ⁎ a School of Chemistry, Madurai Kamaraj University, Madurai-625021, Tamil Nadu, India. School of Chemistry Madurai Kamaraj University Madurai Tamil Nadu 625021 India aSchool of Chemistry, Madurai Kamaraj University, Madurai-625021, Tamil Nadu, India. b Departamento de Química, Universitat Politècnica de València, Camino de Vera s/n, Valencia, 46022, Spain Departamento de Química Universitat Politècnica de València Camino de Vera s/n Valencia 46022 Spain bDepartamento de Química, Universitat Politècnica de València, Camino de Vera s/n, Valencia, 46022, Spain ⁎ Corresponding author. Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) are one of the solid porous materials, frequently used as heterogeneous catalysts for organic transformations. In this aspect, we report here the catalytic performance of Cu3(BTC)2 (BTC: 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) as a solid porous material for the synthesis of 4-styrylquinazolines from the sequential reactions between 2-aminochalcone and alcohols in good yields in short reaction time. Out of the MOFs tested for this transformation, Cu3(BTC)2 shows 86% yield of 2-methyl-4-styrylquinazoline from 2-aminochalcone and ethanol at 60 °C after 10 min. Under these conditions, Cu3(BTC)2 exhibits wide substrate scope for the synthesis of series of 4-styrylquinazoline derivatives. The catalyst stability is also ascertained by performing reusability experiments and the activity is maintained for at least four cycles. In addition, significant changes are observed between the fresh and the four times used solids by powder XRD, FT-IR, UV-Vis and SEM methods. Further, the optimized reaction conditions are also extended to obtain quinazoline derivatives from 2-aminoacetophenone, 2-aminobenzophenone and alcohols. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Quinazoline is one of the most relevant nitrogen-based heterocyclic compounds found in many natural products and medicinal drugs. [1–4] Quinazoline derivatives have received a great deal of interest due to their diverse properties that include biological and therapeutic fields like antibacterial/antidiabetic/anticarcinogen. [5–7] On the other hand, pharmaceutical organizations have showed interest in manufacturing quinazoline based drugs. [8] Synthesis of quinazolines has been reported by various methods that include the reaction between of o‑aminobenzamides and methanol by dehydrogenative coupling, [9] C-H functionalization of 2-aminobenzophenone with benzyl amine, [10] aerobic oxidative decarboxylative amination of aryl acetic acid with 2-aminobenzophenone, [11] annulation of amidine with DMSO, [12] Ullmann type coupling between 2-bromophenylmethylamine and benzamide, [13] ultrasonic irradiation of 2-bromobenzaldehyde with benzamidine hydrochloride, [14] C-H amination/C-N bond cleavage of tertiary amine with 2-aminobenzophenone under aerobic conditions, [15] decarboxylative amination of primary α-amino acid with 2-aminobenzoketone, [16] oxidative amination of 2-aminobenzophenone with DMSO using ammonium acetate, [17] intramolecular C-H amidination of isonitrile with N-arylamidine, [18] 2-aminophenylmethanol with aldehyde catalysed by copper through cascade, [19] annulation reactions between imine with alkyl azides [20] and of nitriles with aryldiazonium salt [21] and oxidative amination of methanol. [22] Furthermore, these heterocyclic compounds were synthesised using heterogeneous catalysts using CeO2 nanoparticles. Also, an effective one-pot method was reported for quinazolinone derivatives bearing the 3-acrylamino motif. [23] In another report, RuO2 nanoparticle was reported as a heterogeneous catalyst for the cyclocondensation of N-(4-methoxyphenyl)-2-(methylamino)benzamide with aldehydes. [24] Further, Cu3(BTC)2 was reported for the synthesis of quinazolinone from 2-aminobenzamide and benzaldehyde. [25] Also, MOFs have also been reported as heterogeneous catalysts/photocatalysts for the synthesis of quinazolin-4(3H)-ones in moderate to good yields. [26–28] While the above mentioned approaches or methods have been reported to produce quinazoline and its derivatives, many of them have some limitations like multistep procedures, corrosive or non-recoverable catalyst and extremely harsh reaction conditions. One of the common issues associated with the use of homogeneous catalysts is their recovery and reuse after the catalytic reaction. Attempts to reuse the homogeneous catalysts failed mostly due to the deactivation or poisoning of the catalysts during the process of the reaction. Particularly, the isolation of the product and removal of trace metal impurities are relatively difficult, often requires tedious purification processes. To overcome these difficulties, heterogeneous catalytic systems offer inherent benefits like facile separation of the solid heterogeneous catalyst with similar inherent properties like the fresh solid from the reaction mixture and hence, the recovered solid can be reused. In this perspective, an identification of new porous solids for organic transformation is always an attracting strategy in heterogeneous catalysis. MOFs are considered as an innovative class of crystalline hybrid porous materials derived by the coordinative linkage of metal ions/clusters with the rigid organic ligands showing applications in many areas. [29–31] Among these applications, the employment of MOFs as solid catalysts is one of the areas, where many research groups are actively working. [32] Hence, MOFs have been effectively exploited as versatile catalysts for various organic processes in the last few decades. Some of the notable properties of MOFs include high surface area/porosity, structural diversity and the existence of high transition metal content. [33] Cu3(BTC)2 is a known porous solid whose structure is assembled by the coordination of Cu2+ ions with the rigid BTC as the linker. It is a known fact that Cu2+ ions in Cu3(BTC)2 contain water molecules that can be facilely removed upon activation, thus creating the Lewis acidity. Due to this intrinsic property of Cu3(BTC)2, it was extensively reported for many organic transformations like ring opening of epoxide, [34] acetalization of aldehyde, [35] oxidation of benzylic hydrocarbon, [36] oxidation of alcohol, [37] oxidation of silane to silanol, [38] N-arylation of benzimidazole, [39] and alkylation reaction of indole with nitroalkene. [40]. Continuing our interest on developing new protocol for organic transformation using heterogeneous solid material based on MOFs, the present work aims to report the catalytic performance of Cu3(BTC)2 for the synthesis of 4-styrylquinazoline by the oxidative amination of 2-aminochalcone with ethanol and NH4OAc in the presence of t-butylhydroperoxide (TBHP). The reaction conditions are optimized to achieve high product yield without compromising the catalyst stability. In comparison to previously reported works, this work reports an effective strategy for the synthesis of the targeted compound since it requires short reaction time (10-20 min), reusability, simple isolation of the product . 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Cu3(BTC)2 also referred in the literature as HKUST-1 (HKUST: Hong Kong University of Science and Technology) was procured at Sigma-Aldrich under the name of Basolite C300. 2-Aminochalcone was synthesised by following the procedure described in an earlier method. [41] 2-Aminoacetophenone, benzaldehyde, ammonium acetate, alcohols, and TBHP were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich with 99% purity and utilised as supplied with no further treatments. The solvents used in this work acquired from commercial sources and utilised as received with no purifications with the following purity MeOH (Sigma Aldrich, 99%, HPLC grade), EtOH (Sigma Aldrich, 99%, HPLC grade), 1-propanol (Sigma Aldrich, 99%, HPLC grade), 1-butanol (Sigma Aldrich, 99%, HPLC grade), 1-hexanol (Merck, 99%, HPLC grade), benzyl alcohol (Merck, 99%, HPLC grade), toluene (Sigma Aldrich, 99%, HPLC grade), acetonitrile (Sigma Aldrich, 99%, HPLC grade), dioxane (Merck, 99%, HPLC grade), ethyl acetate (Merck, 99%, HPLC grade) and hexane (Merck, 99%, HPLC grade) 2.2 Instrumentation 1H-NMR spectra were acquired in CDCl3 using a Bruker (Avance) 400 MHz equipment. The chemical shifts were presented in ppm and are related to tetramethylsilane as reference. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) spectra were collected with a Bruker tensor 27 series spectrometer between 400 to 4000 cm−1 at a resolution of 2 cm−1. The pellet for FT-IR spectra was made by mixing 100 mg of KBr and 5 mg of a sample. SEM images were collected with TESCAN VEGA3 instrument with 20 kV using secondary electron and Backscattered electrons detector. UV-Visible spectra were collected by using UV Jasco V-650 spectrophotometer between the range of 200 to 900 nm by dispersing the sample on the surface of BaSO4. High Resolution Mass Spectral (HRMS) analysis was performed with the Agilent instrument equipped with capillary column, working with Q TOF detector using the mobile phase water: acetonitrile (1:1). The product was matched with Agilent mass hunter workstation. 2.3 Reaction procedure Briefly, 3 mmol of sodium hydroxide was added to a solution of corresponding 2-aminoacetophenone (1 mmol) in ethanol (2.5 mL/mmol) at 0 °C. After 10 min, 1.2 mmol of benzaldehyde derivative was added to this solution. This mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight and the reaction progress was monitored using thin layer chromatography. After completion of the reaction, it was cooled with ice and carefully neutralized with hydrochloric acid (1N). Later, the crude mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate followed by washing with water and brine. Finally, the solid was purified with column chromatography (1 mL ethyl acetate with 9 mL hexane) to obtain the pure product as evidenced by 1H-NMR. The catalytic reaction was performed by introducing 20 mg of Cu3(BTC)2 to the high-pressure borosilicate glass reactor tube (30 mL) consisting of 2-aminochalcone (0.2 mmol), ammonium acetate (0.4 mmol), TBHP (0.2 mmol), alcohol (1 mL) and sealed under atmospheric pressure. Later, this heterogeneous slurry was kept at 60°C (oil bath) for the required time. After the disappearance of 2-aminochalcone as confirmed by thin layer chromatography, the heterogeneous mixture was stirred with acetonitrile (3 mL), washed with methanol (2×2 mL). The mixture was allowed to settle, and methanol was decanted and the tube with the solid catalyst was dried at 120 °C for 5 h. Later, the crude mixture was purified by preparative thin layer chromatography using 1 mL ethyl acetate with 9 mL hexane and the isolated yield was reported in Tables 1 and 2 . The dried solid was used in subsequent cycles with new reactants to perform reusability tests with the similar procedure explained above. All the experiments reported in Table 1, Figs. 1 , 2 and 3 were the average of two independent experiments. The as-synthesised products shown in Table 2 were characterized by 1H-NMR and HRMS and are shown in Figs. S1-S16. 3 Results and discussions Cu3(BTC)2 is a solid crystalline framework whose structure is constituted by the coordination between the clusters of Cu2+ ions with four carboxylate groups from BTC leading to a paddle-wheel building unit. While forming the structure of Cu3(BTC)2, Cu2+ ions were coordinated with solvent molecules to balance the coordination around metal ions. Thus, these solvent molecules or loosely bounded water molecules can be removed upon thermal treatment to create coordinatively unsaturated sites. BET surface area measurement was reported for the fresh Cu3(BTC)2 solid as 1050 m2/g with 11, 16 and 6 Å pore dimensions. [42] Further, fresh Cu3(BTC)2 solid was also characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) and it indicates the presence of high crystallinity and the peak positions, intensities are in good agreement with the reported data. [38,40] As commented above in the introduction, the catalytic performance of Cu3(BTC)2 was examined in the oxidative amination of ethanol with 2-aminochalcone to obtain 2-methyl-4-styrylquinazoline under various experimental conditions. The achieved results are shown in Table 1. Initially, the reaction between 2-aminochalcone and methanol with TBHP and ammonium acetate with Cu3(BTC)2 showed 80% yield after 10 min at 60 °C to afford 4-styrylquinazoline. On the other hand, an identical reaction with ethanol as an alcohol source afforded 86% yield of 2-methyl-4-styrylquinazoline under similar conditions. After the successful formation of the expected product under these conditions, the influence of temperature and catalyst loading was also examined and the observed results are shown in Figs. 1 and 2. Among the various catalyst loadings tested (5, 10, 15 and 20 mg) under the conditions shown in entry 2 (Table 1), the maximum yield was achieved with 20 mg of Cu3(BTC)2. Further, the reaction was conducted at 50, 60 and 80 °C as shown in entry 2 (Table 1), similar yield was observed at 60 and 80 °C. Hence it was decided to keep the temperature at 60 °C for further experiments. Later, this reaction was also successful with 1-propanol to the desired product in 81% yield. However, attempts to use 1-butanol and 1-hexanol as alcohols under similar experimental conditions failed to give the expected products. These results suggest that 1-butanol and 1-hexanol are not oxidized to their respective aldehydes with these similar conditions. Interestingly, the oxidative amination of benzyl alcohol with 2-aminochalcone was successful to obtain 65% yield under identical conditions. The lower yield compared to methanol and ethanol may be due to the lower rate of the oxidation of benzyl alcohol as well as its steric hindrance. Interestingly, this reaction was also performed with toluene, acetonitrile and dioxane under identical experimental conditions and no products were observed. These data clearly suggest that the reaction requires alcohols that can be readily oxidized to their respective aldehydes, which is one of the crucial steps in the formation of quinazoline. The oxidative amination of ethanol using 2-aminochalcone with ammonium acetate involving Cu3(BTC)2 without TBHP showed slightly lower yield (74%) and is believed due to the poor oxidizing ability of Cu(I) to Cu(II). In fact, the oxidative amination of ethanol using 2-aminochalcone with ammonium acetate and TBHP without Cu3(BTC)2 exhibited 13% yield. This experiment unambiguously confirms the need of Cu3(BTC)2 as a catalyst for this transformation. Furthermore, the oxidative amination of ethanol using 2-aminochalcone with ammonium acetate involving Cu3(BTC)2 under oxygen atmosphere provided 72% yield. Under identical conditions, Fe(BTC) and MIL-101(Cr) MOF catalysts afforded 62 and 63% yields, respectively. The integrity of the 2-methyl-4-styrylquinazoline was confirmed by 1H-NMR data recorded with 400 MHz in CDCl3 as a solvent. The proton integrations are given as follows. δ8.27-8.22(m, 2H, aromatic protons), 7.95 (d, 1H, J=8Hz, styryl hydrogen), 7.90 (d, 1H, J=16Hz, styryl hydrogen), 7.84 (t, 1H, J=8Hz, aromatic proton), 7.72 (d, 2H, J=8Hz, aromatic protons), 7.58 (t, 1H, J=8Hz, aromatic proton), 7.46-7.37 (m, 3H, aromatic protons), 2.92 (s, 3H, methyl protons). These assignments are in good agreement with the product, thus, the formation of the product is confirmed (Fig. S2). This work aims to explore the catalytic performance of Cu3(BTC)2 for this transformation without compromising its stability. To prove its stability, reusability experiments were performed as discussed in the experimental section. Fig. 3 shows the catalytic data observed for four cycles and these results indicate that the yield of the product remains similar during three consecutive runs, while there is a slight decay in the yield after fourth cycle. This decay in the yield is believed to be due to the loss of the catalyst, thus lowering in the number of active sites. Furthermore, the structural integrity and morphology of the spent catalyst were also compared with the fresh catalyst and the observed results are discussed below. Fig. 4 provides the diffuse reflectance spectra for the fresh, recovered, three- and four-times used Cu3(BTC)2. The absorbance in the UV and Visible regions for the spent catalyst is almost identical to the initial Cu3(BTC)2. However, the d-d band intensities for the recovered, three- and four-times employed catalysts were lower compared to the fresh catalyst. These observations suggest that the density of Cu2+ ions may be decreased in the recovered and spent catalysts. Fig. 5 compares the FT-IR spectra of the fresh with the recovered and four times used Cu3(BTC)2 catalyst. These results also indicate that the stretching frequencies of the used sample matches with the fresh solid. However, additional peaks in the region of 3300-3400 are seen for the used sample and may be due to the adsorbed water/reactants. Similarly, no changes in the morphology are seen between the fresh and used Cu3(BTC)2 solids (Fig. 6 ). On the other hand, the powder XRD pattern of the four times used solid was compared with the fresh catalyst and the observed results are shown in Fig. S17. These comparisons suggest that although the crystallinity is retained during the reaction for the used solid, the structural integrity and the peak positions have completely changed. This observation is also in agreement with a significant reduction in d-d band intensity of the used solid from diffuse reflectance spectra. Therefore, these combined results indicate that the used solid does not exhibit significant stability compared to the fresh material, thus further studies are required to identify structural transformations within the framework of Cu3(BTC)2. After optimizing the reaction conditions and addressing the stability issues of Cu3(BTC)2, the substrate scope of this catalyst was further tested with series of substituted 2-aminochalcones and the observed catalytic data are presented in Table 2. Under the optimized reaction conditions, the oxidative amination of methanol with 2-aminochalcone afforded 4-styrylquinazoline in 80% yield. Similarly, the oxidative amination of ethanol and propanol with 2-aminochalcone showed 86 and 81% yields, respectively. 2-Aminochalcone derivatives bearing -NO2, -Br, -Me and -OEt were also reacted with ethanol under similar conditions and observing 56-92% yields. Also, the reaction of 2-aminochalcone with benzyl alcohol under these conditions resulted in 65% yield. Interestingly, quinazoline derivatives were also synthesised successfully from 2-aminobenzophenone derivatives and 2-aminoacetophene with ethanol under similar conditions with Cu3(BTC)2 as solid material in 75-92% yields. These data indicate the wide substrate scope of this catalyst to access the targeted compounds from various starting materials. Based on the observed catalytic data, a suitable mechanism for the synthesis of 2-methyl-4-styrylquinazoline is proposed (Scheme 1 ) in respect to previous literature precedents. [16, 22, 43-45] Initially, alcohol (ethanol) was dehydrogenated by the assistance of Cu3(BTC)2 to give acetaldehyde and generates Cu(I), which later was oxidized by TBHP to give Cu(II). Thus, the in situ generated acetaldehyde was condensed with the amino group in 2-aminochalcone to produce the corresponding imine. Subsequently, this imine reacts with NH4OAc to form amine intermediate, which further undergoes intramolecular cyclization, followed by dehydrogenation to afford the desired final product. In order to prove the above mechanistic proposal in where the alcohol is initially oxidized to its corresponding aldehyde, a control experiment was performed as shown in Scheme 2 . Assuming that methanol is oxidized by Cu3(BTC)2 to formaldehyde, a control experiment was performed between 2-aminochalcone and formaldehyde under identical conditions in toluene (1 mL). Interestingly, this experiment afforded the expected product, namely 4-styrylquinazoline in 81% yield. 4 Conclusions We have nicely demonstrated the feasibility of employing Cu3(BTC)2 as a solid material to obtain series of 4-styrylquinazoline derivatives from 2-aminochalcone and alcohols in good yields under short reaction time. This transformation was tested with series of MOFs and the observed catalytic results indicate that Cu3(BTC)2 provides the maximum activity. Further, Cu3(BTC)2 scope was tested with series of 2-aminochalcone derivatives and observing wide range of 4-styrylquinazoline derivatives. The catalyst stability was assessed by reusability tests and the activity is retained for at least four cycles. In addition, the fresh and the four times employed Cu3(BTC)2 solids were compared by powder XRD, FT-IR, UV-Vis and SEM methods and significant changes are observed between these solids, particularly in powder XRD. Further, the optimized reaction conditions were extended to prepare quinazoline derivatives in high yields from 2-aminoacetophenone, 2-aminobenzophenone and alcohols as starting materials. coredata.dc:description: Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) are one of the solid porous materials, frequently used as heterogeneous catalysts for organic transformations. In this aspect, we report here the catalytic performance of Cu3(BTC)2 (BTC: 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) as a solid porous material for the synthesis of 4-styrylquinazolines from the sequential reactions between 2-aminochalcone and alcohols in good yields in short reaction time. Out of the MOFs tested for this transformation, Cu3(BTC)2 shows 86% yield of 2-methyl-4-styrylquinazoline from 2-aminochalcone and ethanol at 60 °C after 10 min. Under these conditions, Cu3(BTC)2 exhibits wide substrate scope for the synthesis of series of 4-styrylquinazoline derivatives. The catalyst stability is also ascertained by performing reusability experiments and the activity is maintained for at least four cycles. In addition, significant changes are observed between the fresh and the four times used solids by powder XRD, FT-IR, UV-Vis and SEM methods. Further, the optimized reaction conditions are also extended to obtain quinazoline derivatives from 2-aminoacetophenone, 2-aminobenzophenone and alcohols.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of 4-styrylquinazolines using copper-based porous solid catalyst
